MouseEvent.summary:
The MouseEvent interface represents events that occur due to the user interacting with a pointing device (such as a mouse).
Common events using this interface include , , , .

remarks.para:
MouseEvent derives from , which in turn derives from .
Though the method is kept for backward compatibility, creating of a MouseEvent object should be done using the constructor.
Several more specific events are based on MouseEvent, including , , and .

-Its direct parent,
-: For advanced pointer events, including multi-touch

MouseEventAltKey.summary: The MouseEvent.altKey read-only property is a boolean value that indicates whether the <kbd>alt</kbd> key was pressed or not when a given mouse event occurs.

remarks.para:
Be aware that the browser can't always detect the <kbd>alt</kbd> key on some operating systems.
On some Linux variants, for example, a left mouse click combined with the <kbd>alt</kbd> key is used to move or resize windows.

blockquote.para: On Macintosh keyboards, this key is also known as the <kbd>option</kbd> key.

MouseEventAltKey.value: A boolean value, where true indicates that the key is pressed, and false indicates that the key is not pressed.

MouseEventButton.summary: The MouseEvent.button read-only property indicates which button was pressed or released on the mouse to trigger the event.

remarks.para:
This property only guarantees to indicate which buttons are pressed or released during events caused by pressing or releasing one or multiple buttons.
As such, it is not reliable for events such as , , , , or .

Users may change the configuration of buttons on their pointing device so that if an event's button property is zero, it may not have been caused by the button that is physically left–most on the pointing device; however, it should behave as if the left button was clicked in the standard button layout.

blockquote.para: Do not confuse this property with the property, which indicates which buttons are pressed for all mouse events types.

MouseEventButton.value:
A number representing a given button:As noted above, buttons may be configured differently to the standard "left to right" layout.
A mouse configured for left-handed use may have the button actions reversed.
Some pointing devices only have one button and use keyboard or other input mechanisms to indicate main, secondary, auxiliary, etc.
Others may have many buttons mapped to different functions and button values.

MouseEventButtons.summary: The MouseEvent.buttons read-only property indicates which buttons are pressed on the mouse (or other input device) when a mouse event is triggered.

remarks.para:
Each button that can be pressed is represented by a given number (see below).
If more than one button is pressed, the button values are added together to produce a new number.
For example, if the secondary (2) and auxiliary (4) buttons are pressed simultaneously, the value is 6 (i.e., 2 + 4).

blockquote.para:
Do not confuse this property with the property.
The MouseEvent.buttons property indicates the state of buttons pressed during any kind of mouse event,
while the property only guarantees the correct value for mouse events caused by pressing or releasing one or multiple buttons.

MouseEventButtons.value:
A number representing one or more buttons.
For more than one button pressed simultaneously, the values are combined (e.g., 3 is primary + secondary).

MouseEventClientX.summary: The clientX read-only property of the interface provides the horizontal coordinate within the application's {{glossary("viewport")}} at which the event occurred (as opposed to the coordinate within the page).

remarks.para: For example, clicking on the left edge of the viewport will always result in a mouse event with a clientX value of 0, regardless of whether the page is scrolled horizontally.

-
-
- /
-Coordinate systems

MouseEventClientX.value: A double floating point value in pixels.

MouseEventClientY.summary: The clientY read-only property of the interface provides the vertical coordinate within the application's {{glossary("viewport")}} at which the event occurred (as opposed to the coordinate within the page).

remarks.para: For example, clicking on the top edge of the viewport will always result in a mouse event with a clientY value of 0, regardless of whether the page is scrolled vertically.

-
-
- /
-Coordinate systems

MouseEventClientY.value: A double floating point value in pixels.

MouseEventCtrlKey.summary: The MouseEvent.ctrlKey read-only property is a boolean value that indicates whether the <kbd>ctrl</kbd> key was pressed or not when a given mouse event occurs.

remarks.para: On Macintosh keyboards, this key is labeled the <kbd>control</kbd> key. Also, note that on a Mac, a click combined with the <kbd>control</kbd> key is intercepted by the operating system and used to open a context menu, so ctrlKey is not detectable on click events.
Pinch-zooming using a trackpad also sends a simulated event with ctrlKey set to true.

MouseEventCtrlKey.value: A boolean value, where true indicates that the key is pressed, and false indicates that the key is not pressed.

MouseEventGetModifierState.summary: The MouseEvent.getModifierState() method returns the current state of the specified modifier key: true if the modifier is active (i.e., the modifier key is pressed or locked), otherwise, false.

remarks.para: See for details.

-The this method belongs to.
-

MouseEventInitMouseEvent.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The MouseEvent.initMouseEvent() method initializes the
value of a mouse event once it's been created (normally using the method).

blockquote.para: Do not use this method anymore as it is deprecated.

Instead use specific event constructors, like .
The section on Creating and dispatching events gives more information about the way to use these.

remarks.para:
Events initialized in this way must have been created with the method.
This method must be called to set the event
before it is dispatched, using .

- constructor, the modern
standard way of creating a
- is a simpler method serving a similar purpose. It
is also obsolete and shouldn't be used any more.

MouseEventLayerX.summary:
CAUTION Non-standard The MouseEvent.layerX read-only property returns the
horizontal coordinate of the event relative to the current layer.

remarks.para:
This property takes scrolling of the page into account and returns a value relative to
the whole of the document unless the event occurs inside a positioned element, where the
returned value is relative to the top left of the positioned element.

MouseEventLayerX.value: An integer value in pixels for the x-coordinate of the mouse pointer, when the mouse event fired.

MouseEventLayerY.summary:
CAUTION Non-standard The MouseEvent.layerY read-only property returns the
vertical coordinate of the event relative to the current layer.

remarks.para:
This property takes scrolling of the page into account, and returns a value relative to
the whole of the document, unless the event occurs inside a positioned element, where
the returned value is relative to the top left of the positioned element.

MouseEventLayerY.value: An integer value in pixels for the y-coordinate of the mouse pointer, when the mouse event fired.

MouseEventMetaKey.summary: The MouseEvent.metaKey read-only property is a boolean value that indicates whether the <kbd>meta</kbd> key was pressed or not when a given mouse event occurs.

remarks.para:
Be aware that many operating systems bind special functionality to the <kbd>meta</kbd> key, so this property may be false even when the key is actually pressed.
On Windows, for example, this key may open the Start menu.

blockquote.para:
On Macintosh keyboards, this key is the <kbd>command</kbd> key (<kbd>⌘</kbd>).
On Windows keyboards, this key is the Windows key (<kbd>⊞</kbd>).

MouseEventMetaKey.value: A boolean value, where true indicates that the key is pressed, and false indicates that the key is not pressed.

MouseEventMouseEvent.summary: The MouseEvent() constructor creates a new object.

remarks.para: -, the interface of the objects it constructs.

MouseEventMovementX.summary: The movementX read-only property of the interface provides the difference in the X coordinate of the mouse (or pointer) between the given move event and the previous move event of the same type.

remarks.para:
In other words, the value of the property is computed like this: currentEvent.movementX = currentEvent.screenX - previousEvent.screenX.
The value is zero for all events other than , , and .

blockquote.para:
Browsers use different units for movementX and screenX than what the specification defines.
Depending on the browser and operating system, the movementX units may be a physical pixel, a logical pixel, or a CSS pixel. You may want to avoid the movement properties, and instead calculate the delta between the current client values (, ) and the previous client values.

remarks.para:
-
-
-Pointer Lock

MouseEventMovementX.value:
A number.
Always zero on any other than mousemove, and any other than pointermove or pointerrawupdate.

MouseEventMovementY.summary: The movementY read-only property of the interface provides the difference in the Y coordinate of the mouse (or pointer) between the given move event and the previous move event of the same type.

remarks.para:
In other words, the value of the property is computed like this: currentEvent.movementY = currentEvent.screenY - previousEvent.screenY.
The value is zero for all events other than , , and .

blockquote.para:
Browsers use different units for movementY and screenY than what the specification defines.
Depending on the browser and operating system, the movementY units may be a physical pixel, a logical pixel, or a CSS pixel.
You may want to avoid the movement properties, and instead calculate the delta between the current client values (, ) and the previous client values.

remarks.para:
-
-
-Pointer Lock

MouseEventMovementY.value:
A number.
Always zero on any other than mousemove, and any other than pointermove or pointerrawupdate.

MouseEventMozInputSource.summary:
CAUTION Non-standard The MouseEvent.mozInputSource read-only property on provides information indicating the type of device that generated the event.
This lets you, for example, determine whether a mouse event was generated by an actual mouse or by a touch event (which might affect the degree of accuracy with which you interpret the coordinates associated with the event).
MouseEventMozInputSource.value:
The following values are possible.
Constant nameValueDescription
MOZ_SOURCE_UNKNOWN0The input device is unknown.
MOZ_SOURCE_MOUSE1The event was generated by a mouse (or mouse-like device).
MOZ_SOURCE_PEN2The event was generated by a pen on a tablet.
MOZ_SOURCE_ERASER3The event was generated by an eraser on a tablet.
MOZ_SOURCE_CURSOR4The event was generated by a cursor.
MOZ_SOURCE_TOUCH5The event was generated on a touch interface.
MOZ_SOURCE_KEYBOARD6The event was generated by a keyboard.

MouseEventOffsetX.summary: The offsetX read-only property of the interface provides the offset in the X coordinate of the mouse pointer between that event and the padding edge of the target node.

remarks.para:
-
-Coordinate systems

MouseEventOffsetX.value: A double floating point value in pixels.Early versions of the spec defined this as an integer.

MouseEventOffsetY.summary: The offsetY read-only property of the interface provides the offset in the Y coordinate of the mouse pointer between that event and the padding edge of the target node.

remarks.para:
-
-Coordinate systems

MouseEventOffsetY.value: A double floating point value in pixels.Early versions of the spec defined this as an integer.

MouseEventPageX.summary:
The pageX read-only property of the interface returns the X (horizontal) coordinate (in pixels) at which the mouse was clicked, relative to the left edge of the entire document.
This includes any portion of the document not currently visible.

remarks.para:
Being based on the edge of the document as it is, this property takes into account any horizontal scrolling of the page.
For example, if the page is scrolled such that 200 pixels of the left side of the document are scrolled out of view, and the mouse is clicked 100 pixels inward from the left edge of the view, the value returned by pageX will be 300.

Originally, this property was defined as a long integer. The CSSOM View Module redefined it as a
double float. See the Browser compatibility section for
details.
See Coordinate systems for additional information about coordinates specified in this fashion.

-
-Coordinate systems

MouseEventPageX.value:
A double floating-point number of pixels from the left edge of the document at which the mouse was clicked, regardless of any scrolling or viewport positioning that may be in effect.This property was originally specified in the Touch Events specification as a long integer, but was redefined in the CSSOM View Module to be a double-precision
floating-point number to allow for subpixel precision.
Even though numeric types both are represented by Number in JavaScript, they may be handled differently internally in the browser's code, resulting in potential behavior differences.See Browser compatibility to learn which browsers have been updated to use the revised data type.

MouseEventPageY.summary:
The pageY read-only property of the interface returns the Y (vertical) coordinate (in pixels) at which the mouse was clicked, relative to the top edge of the entire document.
This includes any portion of the document not currently visible.

remarks.para: See for more information.

-
-Coordinate systems

MouseEventPageY.value: A double floating point value in pixels.

MouseEventRelatedTarget.summary: The MouseEvent.relatedTarget read-only property is the secondary target for the mouse event, if there is one.

remarks.para: That is:

For events with no secondary target, relatedTarget returns
null.
is a similar property for focus events.

MouseEventScreenX.summary: The screenX read-only property of the interface provides the horizontal coordinate (offset) of the mouse pointer in screen coordinates.

blockquote.para: In a multiscreen environment, screens aligned horizontally will be treated as a single device, and so the range of the screenX value will increase to the combined width of the screens.

remarks.para:
-
-
- /
-Coordinate systems

MouseEventScreenX.value: A double floating point value in pixels.Early versions of the spec defined this as an integer referring to the number of pixels.

MouseEventScreenY.summary: The screenY read-only property of the interface provides the vertical coordinate (offset) of the mouse pointer in screen coordinates.

remarks.para:
-
-
- /
-Coordinate systems

MouseEventScreenY.value: A double floating point value in pixels.Early versions of the spec defined this as an integer referring to the number of pixels.

MouseEventShiftKey.summary: The MouseEvent.shiftKey read-only property is a boolean value that indicates whether the <kbd>shift</kbd> key was pressed or not when a given mouse event occurs.
MouseEventShiftKey.value: A boolean value, where true indicates that the key is pressed, and false indicates that the key is not pressed.

MouseEventWebkitForce.summary: CAUTION Non-standard MouseEvent.webkitForce is a proprietary, WebKit-specific numeric property whose value represents the amount of pressure that is being applied on the touchpad or touchscreen.

MouseEventWEBKIT_FORCE_AT_FORCE_MOUSE_DO.summary: CAUTION Non-standard MouseEvent.WEBKIT_FORCE_AT_FORCE_MOUSE_DOWN is a proprietary, WebKit-specific, static numeric property whose value is the minimum force necessary for a force click.

remarks.para: Because WEBKIT_FORCE_AT_FORCE_MOUSE_DOWN is a static property of MouseEvent, you always use it as MouseEvent.WEBKIT_FORCE_AT_FORCE_MOUSE_DOWN, rather than as a property of a MouseEvent instance.

MouseEventWEBKIT_FORCE_AT_MOUSE_DOWN.summary: CAUTION Non-standard MouseEvent.WEBKIT_FORCE_AT_MOUSE_DOWN is a proprietary, WebKit-specific, static numeric property whose value is the minimum force necessary for a normal click.

remarks.para: Because WEBKIT_FORCE_AT_MOUSE_DOWN is a static property of MouseEvent, you always use it as MouseEvent.WEBKIT_FORCE_AT_MOUSE_DOWN, rather than as a property of a MouseEvent instance.

MouseEventX.summary: The MouseEvent.x property is an alias for the property.

MouseEventY.summary: The MouseEvent.y property is an alias for the property.
